channel.title: Computer Science Knowledge Base
channel.description: Last 10 notes on Computer Science Knowledge Base

item.title: Python
item.description: Python is a versatile and widely-used programming language that is used by developers, data scientists, and educators alike. Created by Guido van Rossum and first released in 1991, Python has steadily grown in popularity due to its simplicity and readability.

item.description: HCI (Human Computer Interactions) is a field of computer science (and interdisciplinary with social sciences) that helps to design and analyze hardware, and software interfaces that better suit peopleâ€™s needs.

item.title: ðŸŒ±Basics/Intro
item.description: Hardware is the name we give to the physical components of a computer. The hardware is all the stuff that actually sends the signals (electrical or otherwise) we need to make our computers work.

item.title: ðŸŒ±Basics/Intro
item.description: Networks are everywhere these days. Cars, phones, watches, even fridges1 have connections to a network. Understanding networking is a fundamental aspect of computer science, and better understanding the world we operate in today.

item.title: HTTP
item.description: HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol) is the way most of the web communicates. Itâ€™s the system that governs how your computer talks to servers around the world to retrieve webpages, talk to your online calendar, and even send messages in point of sales systems.

item.title: 5-7. Application
item.description: The application layer is the layer most developers work with. Itâ€™s where web frameworks like react, Flask, and others run. This is the highest layer of abstraction in both the OSI and TCP/IP model, meaning the data from this layer gets encapsulated by every other layer down the stack.

item.title: Linux
item.description: Info History informs some of the technical information, as such this section will include technical info about linux, and some history. This I think is the best way to talk about linux & unix since often the history informs the technical decisions.

item.title: Userspace
item.description: This is the good old operating system you know and love. This is where applications, your desktop, and %90 of computing is done. (5) The Laymanâ€™s Guide to Linux: User Space - YouTube (Covers most things at once, but I would recommend doing other sections first then come back to this video) Package managers Â§ These systems are designed to help a user manage packages (applications and services that run on an OS).
